full_text: In the demo, we will look at the process used to export rate books to an Excel format, edit a rate table, and then import the updated rate table. Let's navigate to the rate book. Click the down arrow. Click rate books. Next, we will find the rate books for personal auto. Click the policy, line field. Select personal auto. Click the search button. We will work with the demo rating rate book. Notice that there are two editions of this rate book. Click the link for addition 2. Notice that this rate book is in an active status. This means that no changes can be made to the rate book. To change this rate book, I'll have to create a new edition. Click the Create new edition button. Click the Addition field. Type 3. The next step is to set when this rate book will become effective. Click the date lookup. Select the date when this rate book will be effective. For the purposes of this demo, I'll select the first day of the next month. Click the Update button. Notice this rate book is now in draft status. This will allow us to change the rates. I could edit the rates using the browser. However, I'm going to export the rate book and edit the rates using Excel. To do this, I'll click the export button. And then select, Export to spreadsheet. I'll download the spreadsheet by clicking the download button. And then, download spreadsheet. Now I can open the spreadsheet I downloaded in Excel. Notice that the first tab of this spreadsheet has details about this rate book. Click the tab for the base rates. Click the Base Rate field. Change the base rate to 94. Click the Save button. We now have to import the base rate change back in. To do this, return to the rate book. Click the Edit button. Select Base Rate. Click the Import button. Click the Browse button. Select the spreadsheet file. Click the Open button. Click OK. Click Update. Select the state. Let's confirm that the change imported. Click Base Rate. The base rate for that coverage is now 94. This completes this demo.

segments.text: In the demo, we will look at the process used to export rate books to an Excel format, edit a rate table, and then import the updated rate table.
Let's navigate to the rate book. Click the down arrow. Click rate books.
Next, we will find the rate books for personal auto. Click the policy, line field. Select personal auto.
Click the search button. We will work with the demo rating rate book. Notice that there are two editions of this rate book. Click the link for addition 2.
Notice that this rate book is in an active status. This means that no changes can be made to the rate book. To change this rate book, I'll have to create a new edition.
Click the Create new edition button. Click the Addition field. Type 3.
The next step is to set when this rate book will become effective. Click the date lookup. Select the date when this rate book will be effective.
For the purposes of this demo, I'll select the first day of the next month. Click the Update button.

Notice this rate book is now in draft status. This will allow us to change the rates. I could edit the rates using the browser. However, I'm going to export the rate book and edit the rates using Excel.
To do this, I'll click the export button. And then select, Export to spreadsheet.
I'll download the spreadsheet by clicking the download button. And then, download spreadsheet.
Now I can open the spreadsheet I downloaded in Excel. Notice that the first tab of this spreadsheet has details about this rate book.
Click the tab for the base rates. Click the Base Rate field. Change the base rate to 94. Click the Save button.
We now have to import the base rate change back in. To do this, return to the rate book. Click the Edit button.
Select Base Rate. Click the Import button. Click the Browse button.
Select the spreadsheet file. Click the Open button. Click OK. Click Update.
state. Let's confirm that the change imported. Click Base Rate.
The base rate for that coverage is now 94. This completes this demo.
